spothunt

Class Playfield

  • java.lang.Object
    • spothunt.Playfield

  • public class Playfield
extends java.lang.Object
    This class takes care of the Playfield.
    It creates and initalises a playfield, it can add/move Players and the MovingSpot and it can also set GoalSpots. It also calculates the new danger scores of the field after each player move.
    This class also includes the functionalities to show where each player is and the total field (including the danger score, coordinates and position of the Spot, GoalSpots and Players).
    Version:
    1.1
    Author:
    Jeroen

      void calculateDangers(int danger, int x, int y)
      Calculates the danger level for a given x,y-coordinate and adjacent coordinates.
      void createGUI()
      Creates the a GUI of the playfield, showing the position of important components and the overall danger level.
      void createPlayers(int playerAmount)
      createPlayers makes a array of new instances of the class Player, given an amount of players.
      void getInformation()
      getInformation returns a text-based representation of where every important component is located.
      It will first show where all Players are located using the following layout: Player z: [x,y].
      Secondly, it will show where the MovingSpot is located on the field as: Spot: [x,y].
      Lastly, it will show where all the GoalSpots are located on the field as: Goal z: [x,y].
      void movePlayer(int player, int x, int y)
      movePlayer will move a player to a new position, given an x and y coordinate and which Player to move.
      void moveSpot(int x, int y)
      moveSpot will move the spot to a new position, given an x and y coordinate.
      void setGoals(GoalSpot[] goals)
      setGoals is used to create the GoalSpots on the field, given an array of GoalSpots.
      void setupPlayfield(int width, int height)
      setupPlayfield is used for initializing each cell of the 2D array (matrix) with the a new instance of the class Cell.
      void showPFValues(int options)
      This shows a text-based representation of the field understandable to users.
      Given the options, it will either just show the plain danger levels per area, a very informative view per area or the danger levels and important components per area.
      Set options 0 will result in the plain danger levels per area, for example:

    • Field Detail

      • cells

        public Cell[][] cells

    • Constructor Detail

      • Playfield

        public Playfield(int width,
                 int height)
        The playfield constructor. This will initalise the playfield with a given width and height.
        It will create a 2D array (matrix) of the field and then call the function setupPlayfield.
        After that is done it will also create a new MovingSpot.
        Parameters:
        width - the width of the field.
        height - the height of the field.
        Since:
        1.0

    • Method Detail

      • setupPlayfield

        public void setupPlayfield(int width,
                           int height)
        setupPlayfield is used for initializing each cell of the 2D array (matrix) with the a new instance of the class Cell.
        Parameters:
        width - the width of the field.
        height - the height of the field.
        Since:
        1.0

      • createPlayers

        public void createPlayers(int playerAmount)
        createPlayers makes a array of new instances of the class Player, given an amount of players.
        Parameters:
        playerAmount - the amount of players that will be playing.
        Since:
        1.0

      • movePlayer

        public void movePlayer(int player,
                       int x,
                       int y)
        movePlayer will move a player to a new position, given an x and y coordinate and which Player to move.
        Parameters:
        player - the player number. This is equal to the array index of player in the Players array.
        x - the new x coordinate.
        y - the new y coordinate.
        Since:
        1.0

      • moveSpot

        public void moveSpot(int x,
                     int y)
        moveSpot will move the spot to a new position, given an x and y coordinate.
        Parameters:
        x - the new x coordinate.
        y - the new y coordinate.
        Since:
        1.0

      • setGoals

        public void setGoals(GoalSpot[] goals)
        setGoals is used to create the GoalSpots on the field, given an array of GoalSpots.
        Parameters:
        goals - an array that consist of type GoalSpots[] and therefore only contains GoalSpots.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getInformation

        public void getInformation()
        getInformation returns a text-based representation of where every important component is located.
        It will first show where all Players are located using the following layout: Player z: [x,y].
        Secondly, it will show where the MovingSpot is located on the field as: Spot: [x,y].
        Lastly, it will show where all the GoalSpots are located on the field as: Goal z: [x,y].
        Since:
        1.0

      • calculateDangers

        public void calculateDangers(int danger,
                             int x,
                             int y)
        Calculates the danger level for a given x,y-coordinate and adjacent coordinates. It also requires a danger level.
        Parameters:
        danger - the danger level of the given x,y-coordinate.
        x - the x coordinate of the subarea.
        y - the y coordinate of the subarea.
        Since:
        1.0

      • showPFValues

        public void showPFValues(int options)
        This shows a text-based representation of the field understandable to users.
        Given the options, it will either just show the plain danger levels per area, a very informative view per area or the danger levels and important components per area.
        Set options 0 will result in the plain danger levels per area, for example:
         0      0       0       1
 0      2       0       3
 1      4       2       2
        Set options 1 will result in a very informative view per area, for example:
         [0,0]0S[0,1]0  [0,2]0  [0,3]1          where S is the MovingSpot.
 [1,0]0 [1,1]2  [1,2]0  [1,3]5P         where P is a Player.
 [2,0]1 [2,1]4  [2,2]2  [2,2]2G         where G is a GoalSpot.
        Set options 2 will result in the danger levels per area and the important components, for example:
         0S     0       0       1       where S is the MovingSpot.      
 0      2       0       3P      where P is a Player.
 1      4       2       2G      where G is a GoalSpot.
        Set options 3 will result in the creation of a GUI instead of a TUI.
        Parameters:
        options - the options level. Depending on an integer varying between 0 and (including) 3, it will result a more extensive informative view.
        Since:
        1.1

      • createGUI

        public void createGUI()
        Creates the a GUI of the playfield, showing the position of important components and the overall danger level.
        Since:
        1.1
